talk.start.para: —Last night I was pointing out that the Stevedoring Levy (Collection) Bill 1998 in its thrust is similar to the Employment Security Bill 1998 that was debated yesterday on the initiative of Senator Sue Mackay. I say that because in both bills there is an expectation that related companies will take responsibility for the wages that a particular member of that group has to pay to its employees. It would be a good thing if these two bills were to set a trend that had general application, but whether that happens remains to be seen.

speech.para: May I say that the Stevedoring Levy (Collection) Bill very much reflects the philosophy of the collective responsibility of people which comes from a different philosophy from that which says each company, each person, each individual, should be responsible for his or her or its own actions. The philosophy which says, `Look, market forces, efficiency and competition should rule the day,' is denied by this Stevedoring Levy (Collection) Bill, as it is with Senator Sue Mackay's Employment Security Bill in so far as it says that actions taken by one particular company should be the responsibility of a whole group.

There are some matters which, if I raise them now, will save time during the committee stage. What I am concerned about are clauses 14 and 15 in part 4 of the miscellaneous section of this bill. Clause 15 provides that an inspector may be appointed in writing by the secretary. That person can be a person employed by the Commonwealth and a person employed by a state or by the Northern Territory. It is a very broad provision. That inspector is given power on the basis of a warrant from a justice of the peace to break into houses to get information that may be relevant to the matters raised by this bill.

It seems to me a very serious business that this bill should provide powers to anybody chosen by the Commonwealth, as long as he is employed by the Commonwealth, to break into people's houses on a warrant issued by a justice of the peace. I have always had great respect for justices of the peace, but I am concerned that lay people, as justices of the peace are, should have the power to give people who are not trained as police are in proper investigative procedures to any employee of the Commonwealth to break into houses to search for documents.

I hope when the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) comes to speak about that he will address that concern. We are seeing our liberties more and more curtailed by provisions such as this. No doubt there will be a suggestion that these sorts of provisions are in other acts. Of course, that is the problem. What happens is that these bills are simply drafted on the basis of precedence and, because the precedent is there, it is said that it is all right.

We have come to the stage where people should be able to walk free and should be able to go about their business without employees of the Commonwealth, with no particular training in this area, breaking into premises to look for documents. They could do it at night, as I look at this. I had not realised that until I went through this provision again. Such a person can use force to come into a person's premises at night to search for documents. It seems to me that that is a matter of great concern.
The other issue I want to address is clause 19 of the Stevedoring Levy (Collection) Bill 1998 which says:

(1) If the Minister is satisfied that more levy has been received by the Commonwealth than is needed for the purpose for which the levy was imposed, the Minister may determine that the surplus is to be distributed in accordance with a scheme prescribed by the regulations for the purposes of this section.
(2) The Consolidated Revenue Fund is appropriated for the purposes of payments under subsection (1).

That allows the minister, by regulations, to apply money for any purposes at all, whether in accordance with this act or outside it. It seems to me to be an extraordinary provision that would allow a minister, without the sanctioning of parliament, at a primary level at least, to spend money for whatever purpose. It may be for paying legal costs, it may be for using in the same way as a grant may be used by the Minister for Finance and Administration, and so on. I think it is a dangerous trend to have money spent by a minister without the sanctioning of parliament.

If that scheme was prescribed by regulations while parliament was not sitting, for example, the money would be spent and disposed of before we came back to do anything about it. It would be all right looking at and disallowing the regulation once the money was spent, but it is a very dangerous trend that I see in the miscellaneous parts of this bill where money is spent according to a scheme which has not been sanctioned by parliament, where we have untrained investigators going into houses on the say-so of a justice of the peace—justices of the peace not trained in the law. It is a very worrying trend which is brought out by this particular bill.

The other thing concerns collection of the levy. Clause 13 of the bill says that if somebody does not pay the levy then that becomes a debt due to the Commonwealth and that the Commonwealth can collect a levy on the basis of evidence provided by a statement or averment in the complaint. What will happen is that stevedoring companies which in no way have contributed to the awful and horrible events that we have experienced on the wharf, as has so eloquently been pointed out by previous speakers, where men were shut out of their job—companies who have treated their workers as they ought to have been treated and have a very appropriate scheme in place to see that the work force is properly cared for and where there is a mutual exchange of responsibilities between employer and employee—are going to have to pay money for something that was not in any way their responsibility. If they do not pay, they are going to be taken to court and the evidence to be used against them will simply be a written statement.

I know, Madam Deputy President, in your high regard—as I have noted over the years—in here for there to be proper evidence, that people should stick by their word and that there ought to be proof, you would understand the real danger in all this. Again, it will be said that this has been done before. Having been done before is no reason why it should be done now, particularly where a decent company that has acted correctly is going to have to pay for a company that has not acted properly, and the evidence against the company which has acted properly is simply going to be an averment, a statement, on a piece of paper. It would be interesting to see who would make the averment, whether it is somebody who knows in fact that the debt is due.

I think the concept behind this act—that there ought to be mutual help and responsibility between a group of companies or a group of people who pursue the same profession, employment or industry—is a good idea. I think it is proper that we come back to a communal idea of things rather than the individualistic one which is presently operating. If we are going to do that, it is proper that we treat everybody fairly so that the one who is responsible for the problems in the first place is not allowed to simply put all their burdens onto somebody else and that those other companies should be treated in the way that clause 4 of this particular bill treats them, not in the way that clause 13 treats them.
Turning to clause 8(1), it says:

(1) Subject to this section, levy on loading or unloading is payable by the person (the responsible person ) who was responsible for the loading or unloading (otherwise than in the capacity of agent of the owner or charterer of the ship).
That of course puts it onto the stevedoring companies. At clause 8(2) it says:
(2) If the responsible person is a body corporate, then the following persons are instead jointly and severally liable to pay the levy:

If in fact Patrick's, in this case, did not pay the levy, then other people are responsible—that is, the responsible person, Patrick's, and each other body corporate that is a related body corporate at the time of the loading or unloading. A responsible body is defined in section 50 of the Corporations Law as being:
(a) a holding company of another body corporate;
(b) a subsidiary of another body corporate; or
(c) a subsidiary of a holding company of another body corporate; the first-mentioned body and the other body are related to each other.
Of course, that concept goes against the stripping exercise that was performed by Patrick in this case, and that is good to see.

I conclude by simply saying that this bill does a lot of good things, though it has to be put into proper shape. But the tendency of government to oppress people must be stopped. Simply because a person belongs to a company, simply because a person may come from a body that is seen as being powerful in the community or simply because a person is in a powerful position does not justify others treating them in a manner less than their civil rights demand.

This is an outrageous bill in terms of the civil rights it treads upon. Everybody—no matter whether they are the poorest or the richest, and all those in between—is entitled to civil rights. To simply pass the provisions that are set out in clause 4 of this particular bill seems to me to be quite outrageous.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I thank senators for their contributions. I think it is clear that the opposition is not serious about waterfront reform. We know they had many years in which to make these changes and all we saw were incremental changes at great cost to taxpayers. We have a different approach, and we believe that we have the basis for real reform which can be achieved.

speech.para: We have an effective statutory regime. Funds will be provided to support the reform and restructuring of stevedoring, not paid for by taxpayers, with all costs recovered by a levy on containers and vehicles. A number of people, particularly Senator Calvert, have argued strenuously and successfully to protect Tasmanian interests, and I note that the opposition now agrees that Tasmania should not be subject to the levy for Bass Strait trade.

The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, Mr Reith, has already announced that there will be an exemption applying to local cargo. It was proposed to introduce an amendment to that effect, but we have been advised of some difficulties with it. Instead, a regulation will be introduced to take effect at the same time as the legislation comes into force. Mr Reith has discussed this approach with the Premier of Tasmania, who accepts it.

The legislation provides considerable incentives to stevedores to drive reform and to meet the government's productivity objec tives. It allows them to reduce the appalling level of overmanning, improve training, reduce the unacceptable level of injury and introduce new technology. It does so in a manner and through a mechanism which ensures high levels of accountability and parliamentary scrutiny. More than two years ago the government committed itself to an active role in bringing desperately needed reform to a waterfront where overmanning and rorts prevailed. With this legislation, we deliver on that promise.

The MUA and the ACTU have now signed up to productivity improvements they have fought and rejected year after year. The legislation will ensure that the government, through the Maritime Industry Finance Co., will be able to pay redundancy benefits to at least 736 Patrick Stevedores employees at absolutely no cost to taxpayers. It will ensure that P&O Ports and indeed other stevedores will be able to implement a similar strategy in the near future. Within a few months, the government, through its unwavering determination, will have achieved dramatic and longlasting reform of the waterfront. The legislation is a key component in bringing that about. I commend the legislation to the chamber.
Amendment agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: STEVEDORING LEVY (COLLECTION) BILL 1998
The bill.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: (1) Clause 5, page 3 (after line 16), after the definition of loading , insert:

local cargo means cargo that is consigned from a port in Australia to another port in Australia, other than cargo that is consigned, on a through sea-carriage document, to or from a port outside Australia. For the purposes of this definition, Australia includes the external Territories.
(2) Clause 5, page 3 (after line 17), after the definition of month , insert:
sea-carriage document means any of the following:
(a) a bill of lading;
(b) a consignment note;
(c) a sea waybill;
(d) a ship's delivery order;
(e) any similar document.
(3) Clause 7, page 5 (after line 18), at the end of the clause, add:
(4) Levy is not payable on the loading or unloading of local cargo.

The opposition moves these amendments to exempt domestic cargo. In his summing up in the second reading, the minister said that domestic cargo for Tasmania will be exempt, but I was not quite sure about his explanation for the rest of domestic cargo in Australia. The drift I got—and I would appreciate some more information on this—is that the rest of Australia's domestic cargo will be exempt, but it will not be done by provision in the legislation; there will be some regulatory arrangement whereby the rest of domestic cargo will be exempt.

The opposition is always willing to cooperate because we are the alternative government and we understand that many things have to be done by regulation. However, with the long history of this sorry saga of the government trying to deal with waterfront reform and the way it has gone about it—on which many senators have eloquently spoken—by trying to destroy the MUA and the workers on the waterfront, the opposition is not exactly trustful at the moment of allowing things to be done by some future regulation. Although it will obviously be a disallowable instrument, once you allow something to be a regulation we know in the Senate that it is basically in the hands of the government and you can only reject a regulation.

It is very difficult to make policy by regulation or amend it in the Senate. You can keep rejecting it and the government can keep putting in another regulation. We are very cautious at the moment about leaving this to a commitment from the government to do it by regulation. We would like much more information as to why this has to be done by regulation rather than, as we are proposing, by—

talk.start.para: —Read the constitution.

—Thank you, Senator Calvert. If that is the case, then the minister should have explained it in his summing up of the second reading debate. We would like to get much more detail on the record from the minister and from the government as to why we can trust this being done by regulation rather than by what we are proposing, which is an amendment to the legislation that is open, clear and transparent to everybody.

speech.para: Minister, before I move formally and ask for a vote on our amendments, I would like you to respond in more detail about how this is going to be achieved by regulation. At the moment, the opposition is in no position to trust this government on anything it says about the waterfront in view of the fact that your government has consistently misled the Australian public and the parliament over policy issues on the waterfront.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Firstly, we would not be interested in ratting on an agreement with the Premier of Tasmania, Tony Rundle. In fact, we would not be able to discriminate in favour of Tasmania and against other states. Given that we have reached publicly disclosed agreement with the Premier, clearly the benefits of that will flow on to other states as well. The regulatory approach avoids some of the constitutional difficulties that are implicit in legislation that may or may not be invalid in terms of discrimination between states.

speech.para: If you came to government, Senator Schacht, you would have the ability to proclaim regulations to give effect to this across the board, so it is not just for the benefit of Tasmania, but it gives you all the flexibility you require, and it does not expose you to some of the constitutional and other legal difficulties that might flow from trying to embed it in legislation.

talk.start.para: —On this matter, Minister, are you saying that even the exemption for Tasmania, which is an agreement reached between Mr Reith and Mr Rundle, would be covered by regulation?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am saying that that is simply the most visible aspect of what will be an across-the-board exemption for local cargo. Tasmania was particularly concerned. Mr Reith had discussions with the Premier, who agrees that regulation is preferable in these circumstances and, because you cannot discriminate between states, the benefits will flow through to the other states. So all states will get the same benefits; it was just that Tasmania was the one that was most visible in raising its concerns.

—It seems to me that it is important, firstly, to protect Tasmania, it being the state most reliant on the coastal trade and the state that would have potentially suffered most from the imposition of a levy on its cargo, given the unsatisfactory state of the so-called undertakings to absorb the levy by Patrick's and P&O and, certainly, no undertakings by Brambles, for example, which is heavily engaged in that cargo. It seems to me that, in relation to the argument that the minister puts that somehow the constitution is relevant to whether this matter is dealt with by regulation or amendment, if there is a constitutional problem with an amendment to the legislation, then the sublegislative prescription—the regulation—would be subject to the same problem.

speech.para: It would also be much more appealing to me, representing the state of Tasmania, if this matter were clear from day one, and that, at the point where this bill is being voted on at the third reading stage, all parties—be it the Tasmanian Premier, the government, the opposition, the other parties, the stevedores, or the users of stevedoring services—knew that this matter was put beyond doubt. The way to put it beyond doubt is to carry the amendment that the opposition has moved. In the interests of my state, I urge the government to reconsider its position, to accept the amendment, or to show us what the actual difficulties are with the words of the amendment so that we can understand why there is a difficulty. Frankly, I cannot understand what the difficulty is—and it has not been enunciated.

It has not been enunciated for the Senate; it has not been enunciated publicly anywhere else, as far as I am aware. It may have been enunciated for the Premier of Tasmania but, as far as I am aware, he has not revealed any difficulties with this approach. I suggest that he would be quite happy, as would the whole of Tasmania, with the amendment moved by the opposition. Indeed, all states would be happy with the certainty that our amendment would give this legislation in relation to ensuring that containers carried by sea to all parts of Australia, by way of domestic trade, would be exempt from the levy. That is the sole purpose of this amendment. Minister, the point ought to be made clear as to why there is a technical problem—if there is a technical problem—with the amendment so that we can consider this properly now, resolve this matter now, and have certainty on this matter, before this bill is passed by the Senate.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —If the opposition is interested in certainty, I will give it to them. We will undertake that, as soon as the regulation making power is in place, a regulation will be proclaimed as soon as possible thereafter which will give full effect to this, and not just for the benefit of Tasmania, but for the benefit of all other states. In that way, you will be free of any constitutional challenge. You will have what you want. What you want is certainty that Tasmania and the rest of the states will be protected, and they will be protected by a regulation which will be proclaimed as soon as possible, which I understand to mean a matter of days. So if you want maximum certainty, you will get it.

—The issue raised by Senator O'Brien should be answered. Can you give us an example of where a regulation was able to do more than the act that it depended upon? That is what he is asking, and I think that has got to be answered. In my view, from what I have read over the years, regulations cannot go beyond the power given to them by the act, and that is what Senator O'Brien is asking about. I think we need an answer.

—Minister, our amendment proposes that all domestic cargo, between all states and territories of Australia, be exempt. Therefore, how can that be constitutionally challenged? If our amendment was proposing that the exemption only be for one or two states, then I would agree with you that it could be constitutionally challenged in that we would be discriminating against one state or another. But we are not proposing that. We are proposing an amendment that does not name any state or territory. It is an exemption for all domestic trade, and we have the sovereign right to make legislation about that, under the Australian constitution. You say our amendment is going to be constitutionally challenged, when we are not playing footsies or having favouritism between states or territories. Until you can answer that, Minister, we think you are up to no good.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I have told you that we have precisely the same aim and objective as you do. Do you want to get political advice on how to stall the bill or do you want to get an answer to the question you have just asked?
—If you want to play that game, Richard, we'll be here for days.
—Do you want an answer or not? You cannot do two things at once. I will give you the answer. Let them play their little games on the side when someone else is talking.
—You talk all the time to your advisers and I don't abuse you about it. So don't abuse me when I'm talking to one.
—Order! Senator Schacht!
—The answer is that not only are there constitutional problems that arise when you discriminate between states but there are also concerns about—
—We're not discriminating between states, you dope.

—Just a minute! About adhering to your international obligations, and you know as well as I do that the scrutiny that is brought to bear by bodies such as the WTO is very much focused on legislation. If you want to make sure that you have maximum flexibility, the best way to do it is by regulation. If you want to run the risk of having one form of words that turns out to be wrong, then you put it in legislation. If you want to have the flexibility to be able to ensure that you comply with your international obligations but achieve the objective that I have given you a guarantee that we will implement, then you do it by way of regulation.

—Now, for the first time, we have extra information provided. After three questions to the minister, he now mentions the WTO. But we are talking about domestic trade. As I understand it, the WTO is about international trade. How can you now raise that we have a problem with the WTO, Minister, when we are only talking about domestic trade? So we have knocked you over on the constitutional argument because there is no discrimination in our amendment between states or territories; it is about domestic trade. Now you are raising the WTO, but that is about international trade and this amendment is about domestic trade.

speech.para: How can you raise the issue of the WTO, on the advice that you have got? Many people in this parliament as well as elsewhere in Australia will be staggered to hear that we cannot make decisions about our own domestic trade because it is in contravention of the WTO, which is an international trade arrangement.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I have told you I gave the WTO as an example—
—As an example?

—Of international obligations. It is particularly important to ensure that legislation complies. Our view is that you have much more flexibility and confidence that you will achieve your objective if you go down this path. Do you want to see local cargo exempted in all states or don't you? We guarantee it by regulation. You want to put in place legislation that may or may not turn out to be valid. If you want absolute certainty, you give the same undertaking that we give. You go down that path, you put in a regulation making power and you allow that regulation to come into force as soon as possible. That is the only way in which you will get certainty. If you do not want certainty, you are simply playing games.

—Minister, it is extraordinary to say that you will get more certainty by regulation—regulations as yet unsighted. You have not even given us a draft of the regulation. I would have thought that, if this would give us more certainty than our amendment, you would have fronted up today and given us a draft of the actual regulation.

speech.para: That is not available, so we are asked to buy a pig in a poke. As I say, the record of this government does not commend us to have any trust in buying something on regulation. You have not been able to answer either of the two issues I have raised with you. The constitutional argument you raise is absolutely flawed, because we are not discriminating between states and territories in our amendment. And you cannot answer the argument that domestic trade is subject to the WTO, the World Trade Organisation. You only qualified your words and are now saying `Maybe'. That is unsatisfactory. The opposition will insist on its amendment, and we will get on with the job of putting certainty for the Australian people into the legislation.

talk.start.para: —The Australian Democrats will be guided throughout the consideration of these bills by two considerations; firstly, that the bills are primarily for the benefit of retrenched workers; and, secondly, that the matter is urgent. Accordingly, I should advise my Labor colleagues in the Senate that I have listened to this discussion and what I have heard very clearly from the minister is as follows. He has given an unequivocal guarantee that local cargo will be exempt. Frankly, I think the Labor Party's choice of route is better—a legislative route—but if the govern ment introduces it by regulation and does so soon enough, I and you will be content if it happens. Your concern, Senator Schacht, is that it might not happen.

speech.para: A minister of the crown has guaranteed that it will happen—and very seldom in my experience have I heard Senator Alston, of all people, unequivocally give such a guarantee. Because of that and because of the need for speed and to look after those workers, I will accept the minister's guarantee and I will not vote for Labor Party amendments (1) and (3) if the minister is opposed.

I wish to ask a question of the minister concerning item (2) on sheet 1061. Minister, item (2) seems to me to provide a helpful additional definition. It is possible that the wording of the definition may in fact exclude legitimate matters which should have been included. If you were inclined to accept amendment (2), I would obviously accept that, but if you were inclined to reject it and the word `means' were changed to `includes', would that second definitional amendment on sheet 1061, item (2), be acceptable to government? What is your attitude to that, please?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am not clear what Senator Murray is referring to on the latter point, but on the first point I am grateful for the acceptance of our undertaking. I can go further in providing a copy of the draft regulation in the not too distant future.
—That is today, some time?
—Yes, within a matter of minutes, as I understand it. If Senator Murray could explain to me a little more carefully—for my benefit—what he was referring to, then I will certainly answer it.
—These have all been moved together. Frankly, I would have preferred if (1) and (2) had been moved together and (3) separately.
—Are you talking about the amendments standing in the name of Senator Schacht?
—Yes, I am. Item (2)
—I see, item (2) about the levy. That is the Sealand amendment, is it?

—No, we are referring to sheet 1061. Item (2) has a definition on the sea-carriage document. Perhaps, Minister, I can recap. If you refer to sheet 1061, items (1) to (3) were moved together, but item (2) is distinct, in my view, from items (1) and (3), which refer to the matter which has been previously discussed. Item (2) is a definitional addition which struck me as being helpful, and I wondered what your attitude was to the definition and, if you were inclined to reject it, whether changing the word `means' to `includes' would be acceptable to you. I just need to know your attitude to all three of the amendments which are before us.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I think the short answer is that amendment (2) provides a definition of sea-carriage document but that is relevant only because it is amplifying what is contained in amendment (1). In other words, amendment (1) talks about sea-carriage document, and if you do not proceed with item (1) then there is no point in defining in amendment (2) what you meant.

—As I understand it, the government is going to carry out the intent of the amendments moved by Senator Schacht by means of regulations. But clause 7 of the bill is very specific. It says, `Levy is payable', and it imposes a series of levies on containers and on self-propelled loading of vehicles. So that is very specific. Every container and every vehicle described in clause 7 is going to have to pay the levy.

speech.para: As I understand it—and this is what I want an explanation about—the regulations are going to have to be made under clause 20. There seems to be nothing, as I read down the regulations there, that would enable the government—or anybody else for that matter—to make regulations that override the requirements of clause 7. Indeed, there is no provision in the regulations power that would enable you to do it. Regulation 1 states:
The Governor-General may make regulations prescribing matters:
(a) required or permitted by this Act to be prescribed;
There is nothing that would permit an exemption in the act. The regulation further states:
. . . necessary or convenient to be prescribed for carrying out or giving effect to this Act.

Again, there is nothing in there. If you look at subsection (2) of the regulation power contained in section 20, there is nothing in there. What I would be interested to know is where you are going to get the power in the bill, or from the act if the bill becomes an act, to make the regulations. If you read the bill as a whole, it is quite contrary to the regulations that you want to make. If you look at the regulation power, there is nothing in there to enable you to do it.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer is that the regulation making power is contained in the imposition bill, not the collection bill. If Senator Cooney looks at clauses 5 and 6, he will see that 5 permits a zero rate to be prescribed and 6 permits regulations to be made to give effect to any part of clause 5.

—There is one other matter about this levy. Does the exemption on domestic trade on levy mean that a car going on a fast ferry from Cape Jervis to Kangaroo Island—which is very important for the tourist trade on Kangaroo Island—would have to pay the levy or not under your regulation?
—No levy.

interjection.para: That the amendments (Senator Schacht's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: (1) Clause 5, page 3 (after line 17), after the definition of month , insert:
payment in connection with this Act means a payment:

(a) upon termination of employment, to a person employed in the stevedoring industry, equivalent to the payment that person would normally expect to receive upon termination of his or her employment on the ground of redundancy, including:
(i) redundancy pay; and
(ii) payments in lieu of notice; and
(iii) payments for accrued leave entitlements; and
(b) funded, directly or indirectly, from amounts raised by the levy imposed by the Stevedoring Levy (Imposition) Act 1998 .
(3) Clause 18, page 12 (lines 2 to 4), omit subclause (1), substitute:
(1) The Minister may authorise payments for the reform or restructuring of the stevedoring industry provided that such payments are for the purpose of:
(a) payments in connection with this Act; or
(b) the reasonable costs of administering the scheme.
(4) Clause 18, page 12 (after line 4), after subclause (1), insert:

(1A) The Minister must not authorise payments for the purpose of paragraph (1)(a) except in relation to persons employed by stevedoring companies that were employers of stevedoring labour on 30 June 1997.

These amendments are specifically designed to ensure that the payments are not made to the Patrick companies but go to where we want the money to go—that is, to the workers. Again, this is about honesty and ensuring that this government does not slip out of its obligations. As I have said before, the opposition on this matter does not take the word of the government because we believe there is now a demonstrably proven history that this government will say one thing in parliament and do another thing privately as part of their obsession to attack the workers in the Maritime Union. These recommendations are open and transparent, to make sure that the appropriation—the money being provided by the levy—goes to the workers in accordance with the agreements reached in negotiation. These amendments are consistent with the recommendation of the minority report from the Labor members of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee.

We understand the government has indicated broad support for this approach but has yet to give us a form of words despite a number of meetings. I do not know whether that is still the case or whether they have given us further indication of what the form of words are and whether they will accept this amend ment. It seems to us it is just good public policy to accept this amendment. If this form of words is not appropriate and you have a better form of words, being a cooperative and constructive opposition, we will be willing to have a look at it. But we believe, as a minimum, our amendments should stand because they will ensure, in an open and transparent way, that what the parliament desires to happen will happen and there is no backsliding from the government.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —We will not support the amendments moved by the opposition, but we will support an amendment that the Australian Democrats have put forward. The reasons are briefly these: the opposition amendments would limit the purposes for which payments may be authorised by the minister under clause 18. We have noted the concerns of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee which has itself proposed amendments that would specify the limits of the power of the minister. However, the effects of the limitations proposed by the opposition would be to inappropriately circumscribe the minister's powers. So we are proposing to support the Democrats on the reporting arrangements.
—Is that on sheet 1054?
—Yes, I think that is right.
—That is the Democrat amendment. You circulated to the Senate a government amendment.
—We would not support the Democrat one on 1054, but we would support the Democrat reporting one on 1059.

—Can I ask, Minister, if the government amendment sheet covers the same area. If it does, are you withdrawing that in favour of the Democrat amendment? There is one here without a number on it. Madam Chairman, can you put a number on it to help us?
—I cannot put a number on it. It is to clause 18, page 12, lines 2 to 4.
—The one without the number on it we are not withdrawing.
—That covers a completely different area from the Democrat one. Did I get that clear?
—Yes.
—Thank you. Minister, did you circulate any amendment that you have now withdrawn in favour of the Democrat amendment on this matter?
—No.

—I think it is rather curious that the government is not prepared to accept the amendment that Labor proposes. In the inquiry stage of this bill, it was clear from the evidence given by Mr Corrigan that the only matter that seemed to him relevant to the seven benchmark areas with which he had undertaken to comply as a quid pro quo for accessing the provisions of this legislation was to achieve redundancies. So the Labor Party's amendment in relation to this matter is clearly attending to the only matter that Mr Corrigan put forward as relevant to achieving those seven benchmark achievements which were proposed by the government when they announced this stevedoring bill prior to Easter.

speech.para: Having seen what is reported to have been Mr Corrigan's comments in the Australian Financial Review this morning, I can foresee that Mr Corrigan and Patrick's are going to use what is effectively a suggestion that they will not pass on savings they achieve through reform unless they get more money from this government one way or the other. Leaving the bill as it stands allows the minister to be pressured in that regard given the total discretion that I believe he will have in determining just what matters will attract payments under this bill.

I am not very satisfied that this parliament will pass legislation which will allow this game to take place, because there is no doubt that Patrick's and Mr Corrigan will play whatever games they can to get their hands on further Commonwealth moneys. I think the gambit has already commenced. If you want any further evidence of the lack of good faith in this matter from Mr Corrigan, you have only to see what is reported in today's paper, where he says of the negotiations with the Maritime Union:

"People who want you to believe this could have been achieved through peaceful negotiations are living in fantasy land," he said. "There is a timeframe of more than two years [of negotiation] where we achieved nothing."

That absolutely contradicts the evidence that we received that there were 217 jobs on the table last year and Mr Corrigan's excuse to the Maritime Union for not being able to agree at that time was that he did not have any money to pay redundancies. He is not even being honest with the newspaper reporter who quoted him when he said that nothing was achieved. It was achieved.

There is only one thing which will come out of leaving the bill as it currently stands in relation to the total discretion of the minister to make payments, and that is to allow Mr Corrigan and Patrick's to play the game to try to get public moneys up-front to fund whatever costs he wants to have funded, and we really do not know what they could be because of the breadth of this bill in this regard. In relation to that matter, he will then have the benefits of his competitors, if the bill is not amended in the way we propose later, funding the making of those payments to Patrick.

It may be that P&O seeks similar assistance. We do not know. What this parliament has to do is make certain that this bill provides for bona fide redundancy payments and associated administrative costs. That is what the Labor amendment proposes. That will give this parliament certainty, and that will prevent the minister being willingly or unwillingly forced to make extra payments to Patrick outside of that area.

talk.start.para: —As I understand it, the opposition is moving amendments 1, 3 and 4 on sheet 1041. The minister has said that the government opposes the Democrat amendment on sheet 1054, which does seem to be in the same sort of area as that, but supports the amendment on sheet 1059 as a substitute for the opposition's amendment. The amendment on sheet 1059 seems to have nothing to do with the matters that Senator Schacht and Senator O'Brien have addressed. Sheet 1059 talks about `Reports by Minister'. Could the minister clarify that? That seems to be a different issue from the issues that have been addressed so far by Senator Schacht and Senator O'Brien?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer is that the amendment on sheet 1059 relates to reporting, and I made that clear before. The vice that we see in the opposition amendments, and they are substantially mirrored by the Democrat amendment, is that they are far too narrow.
—Oh!

—I will come to that in a second. Taking Senator O'Brien's point, Mr Corrigan has publicly signed off on an agreement that will involve a certain number of redundancies at no cost to the taxpayer on the basis that they will absorb those costs. If that is not the case or if there is anything that we believe is not in good faith support of those arrangements, then there is the discretion in the minister not to proceed to make payments.

speech.para: The difficulty we have with the opposition amendments is that they are very narrow. They only allow payments for a very small number of specific items. It seems to us that that would allow payments to redundant employees, but it would not allow the minister to make a number of other payments that are essential for the scheme to facilitate reform and restructuring. Particularly, they would not allow the making of payments to a third party for the purpose of assisting third party payments to redundant stevedores.

That is exactly the mechanism we have in mind by establishing MIFCo. We have been advised that that approach will minimise the up-front call on taxpayers' funds. Furthermore, opposition and Democrat amendments would not allow the government to support reform initiatives such as occupational health and safety programs, training programs, the introduction of new technology or the improvement of wharf facilities. Those additional matters are all contained in our government amendments.

talk.start.para: —We're just going to give Corrigan a bagful of money, are we?

—No, quite the opposite. That is why I say, if you look at the very beginning of it, it says, `The Minister may authorise the following payments.' We have the ultimate discretion. If we think that what Mr Corrigan or anyone else is doing is not in line with those agreements, then we simply do not pay. We want the flexibility to pay via not only third parties but also the range of matters that are contained in that amendment which are not simply confined to the redundancy, pay in lieu of notice and accrued leave entitlements that are the substance of the opposition amendments.

—The minister has just explained exactly why we are insisting on our amendment, and as Senator O'Brien has pointed out. In our view, the Democrat amendment does not go far enough in limiting the range of payment. What you want is the flexibility to make payments beyond what most people believe this legislation is designed for with the redundancy payment. We make that quite clear in our amendment (3)—and we do not apologise for this—because our amendment on sheet 1041 says:

speech.para: (1) The Minister may authorise payments for the reform or restructuring of the stevedoring industry provided that such payments are for the purpose of:
(a) payments in connection with this Act; or
(b) the reasonable costs of administering the scheme.

You are after a much wider scope to make payments where you think they are necessary. For example, you may be called to pay the substantial legal costs which have been incurred by Mr Corrigan and others in the courts over recent months as part of the conspiracy to try to destroy the MUA. You can say you will do this by regulation but, as I say, once it is in regulation it is much harder for the parliament to control and to have a view about it than if it is in the legislation as specifically prohibited.

When you mention `new technology' as a definition, what does new technology mean? Does it mean that you can be called upon by Mr Corrigan to buy new equipment for the wharf under the guise that that is new technology? That is a definition the lawyers would have a field day fighting over in a dispute. Of course they will collect their fee on the way through which you might as well pay for out of this fund.

As I said when we debated the previous amendment, the opposition does not trust the government on this matter—full stop. We do not accept the word of the minister, Mr Reith, because he has been proven demonstrably to have misled parliament and the Australian people about his involvement with Mr Corrigan on this matter. The Prime Minister was shown earlier this week to have misled the Australian people as well.

Therefore, we are going to propose amendments that, as Senator O'Brien has already said, specifically tie down where substantial amounts of money are going to be collected and where they are going to be paid. We do not trust the minister having a discretion in this area, particularly this minister, Mr Reith. Therefore, that is why we insist on the proposal we have in sheet 1041 which specifically and clearly defines the purpose for which the payment can be made.

Minister, if you have, as a result of the lessons you have learnt over the last three months in trying to deal with waterfront reform, had a conversion on the road to Damascus, so to speak, and you want to propose in the future using some of the money in various areas for further waterfront reform—either in the equipment area or for further redundancies, or for a number of those other areas you mentioned—come back to the parliament with the legislation. That is how we will know that we will get an outcome that we, the workers and the Australian people will not get doublecrossed on. As far as it goes, we believe that you cannot object to Senator Murray's amendments.

talk.start.para: —He objects to Senator Murray's amendments.
—In relation to reporting.

—Okay, relating to the reporting, but the substance of our amendment means that we will hold the government absolutely to what it does by legislation and not let it get out of it. We do not want to give discretion to this minister to go off and have, as Senator O'Brien has said, his arm twisted by Mr Corrigan. Why wouldn't Mr Corrigan be able to twist the arm of Mr Reith when they are both up on a conspiracy case?
—Corrigan has also proved to be a lot smarter than Reith.

—Yes, on a lot of areas. I agree with Senator Quirke on that. Why wouldn't Mr Corrigan be able to have some influence over the minister, because if they are up on a conspiracy case together Mr Corrigan's evidence may well be germane to the political future of this minister? Isn't that an influence that could be used to get the minister to make further payments to the advantage of Mr Corrigan beyond the scope of what ordinary Australians believe this levy bill is about and how the money can be spent? Therefore, the opposition will insist on its amendments.

—The Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) has been saying that this has all been done without cost to the taxpayer and therefore it is all right. I take it that he means by that that this is a levy and not a tax. But it is a levy imposed on people other than the person that gave rise to this problem, namely, Patrick's. We as a parliament have to be concerned about those other persons who have to pay a tax or a levy—we could argue about that but, in any event, it is other people's money—to accommodate Patrick's.

speech.para: That money is money that the government raises by a means similar to a tax. It is money that is left to be distributed at the discretion of the minister. If you look at clause 19 of this bill, it enables in its terms the minister to use the money for anything. It reads:
. . . the surplus is to be distributed in accordance with a scheme prescribed by the regulations for the purposes of this section.

That is clause 19. In theory at least, any scheme could be prescribed. That money which has been raised from people—it certainly includes Patrick's but goes beyond Patrick's—is money that I think we as a parliament have to look at in the same way as we would look at taxes raised from people. To simply say that no taxpayers' money is involved in this, therefore it does not matter, does an injustice to those stevedoring companies that sit outside Patrick's. There must be some limitation to the breadth of clause 18 which leads to an unlimited discretion as set out in clause 19. I think that the matters raised by Senator Schacht should be persisted with.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer is that clause 19 is couched in wide terms quite deliberately, and the opposition has not indicated any disagreement with it. It is there to cater for the situation where there might be an overcollection with hindsight—
—An overcollection?

—It is precisely what happened, for example, with the gun levy that was collected through Medicare. You do not precisely know what the true cost is going to be. You raise what you think is a reasonable estimate, but you require yourself to spell out what you are going to do with any surplus proceeds. It is significant that, despite the broad terms in which clause 19(1) is couched and to which the opposition has taken no objection, if you look at our amendment, you will see that is couched in much narrower terms. Our amendment reads:

speech.para: . . . payments in connection with the following activities—
that is, occupational health and safety programs, training programs and the introduction of new technology—
that are undertaken after the commencement of this Act in connection with the reform or restructuring of the stevedoring industry . . .

It is very much to do with the overall package. Corrigan and P&O are both on the record as undertaking to absorb the costs within their own structures, not to pass them on, and at no cost to the taxpayer. We regard that as the essence of this agreement.

talk.start.para: —He told us he didn't know about Dubai too, didn't he?

—We can discuss other matters at another time. The important point to remember is that we have the ultimate discretion to pay or not to pay. The advice, as I have indicated, is that your amendment is very narrow.
—Yes, but specifically so.

—But it does not even allow payments to be made through MIFCo, yet MIFCo is by far the most effective way of ensuring payments are targeted. Unless you have a third party capacity, then you are simply limited to the very narrow items that are specified in your amendment.

speech.para: We need that flexibility. We will do it in aid of reform or restructuring of the industry. Training programs and the other matters are very important in many respects in ensuring that these agreements and undertakings do result in significant productivity gains. So we want to have that flexibility to ensure that it happens at no cost to the taxpayer.

talk.start.para: —Amendments Nos 1, 3 and 4 put forward by the opposition on sheet 1041 enables those people other than Patrick's who have paid the levy—who, after all, are entitled to the consideration of this parliament and to a degree at least of fairness and consideration—to have criteria against which they can measure whether or not their money is being properly spent. It allows for accountability and transparency which, after all, is what we are supposed to provide to those people who pay money to the government, whether you want to call them taxpayers or you want to call them levy payers. Nevertheless, it is money taken by the government from people that have in no way incurred a liability for it outside the legislation. All this is imposed on them by what we do. Certainly, they are entitled to some sort of accountability and transparency, if they are to get Patrick's off the hook they are on. The opposition has put forward some provisions which, far from being too narrow, are probably too broad. I think that, as a matter of justice to those stevedoring companies outside Patrick's, this sort of provision should be made explicit.

—I want to touch on the explanation that the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) gave on the government's own amendments on this matter and explain very clearly why we do not believe the government's amendments are appropriate. To broaden the scope for the making of payments under this legislation is to open up a great range of opportunities to make payments, potentially inappropriately, that will be entirely at the discretion of the minister.

speech.para: The government's proposed amendment, where payments could be made, for example, for the introduction of new technology or for the improvement of wharf facilities, is a great example of where the minister could effectively pick winners or favour one particular operator against another and, through this bill, potentially impose the cost on competitors. That is what this bill does. When the previous WIRA proposals were put in place, there was common employment and you did not have an employer based set of arrangements that had to be funded separately. There was funding which went into a whole pool of employment.

Now we are talking about a different situation on the waterfront where there are individual employers. You are, by this legislation, going to target—advantage or disadvantage, potentially—individual employers, one against the other, port against port, facility against facility, and all that we have to control that is the minister's discretion and the reporting of the exercise of that discretion. There is no role for the parliament to control that other than to receive a report.

In terms of the Labor Party's amendments, we say clearly that no item has been identified as needing expenditure at this stage other than redundancies. If the Democrats are concerned that the passage of this bill not impede the settlement on the waterfront that has been achieved, let them demonstrate that something more than what we propose is needed at this time.

If matters arise—and let me say we had P&O and Patrick before us at the committee and none of their evidence indicated that other matters specifically needed funding—all I can say is that the government's amend ments will leave great loopholes in the making of payments: firstly, inappropriately for the benefit of one competitor against another, or for one port against another, funded by the operations of another port or a competitor under this legislation; and, secondly, they will leave a great loophole in the making of payments ostensibly for one purpose when in fact they are for another. Notwithstanding what is proposed in relation to reporting, I believe that the means would still be available for the making of payments, even if they were ostensibly for one purpose when in fact the moneys supplied were used for another.

I suggest that the only responsible course for the Senate today is to pass the opposition's amendments. If there are further matters that the government can bring before the Senate which justify further amendments, then that is quite possible, but there is no pressing need for the breadth of the bill that is proposed now.

talk.start.para: —What particularly concerns the opposition, as Senator Cooney and Senator O'Brien have pointed out, is that when we look at the government amendments—which are not on a numbered sheet but are on the only government sheet that has been circulated with amendments, which I will call the government amendments—we see that (c) says:

speech.para: . . . payments in respect of activities that are prescribed by regulation, being activities in connection with the reform or restructuring of the stevedoring industry . . .

We believe that definition is far too wide. It will provide the opportunity, as Senator O'Brien and Senator Cooney have said, to play favourites, to make arrangements to put different amounts into different companies.

New technology is also mentioned. Only recently there was a story in the media where Mr Corrigan was quoted as speculating about introducing a fully robotic wharf operation. That is new technology. I must say there would be a fair bit of concern in the community if we suddenly found that some of this money was being used to encourage—without proper discussion and consultation with all the parties concerned—a fully robotic wharf and that it was to be paid for out of public money through this device without proper debate.

Our concerns are about the way you have put your amendment and the structure of it. In the climate of mistrust that this government has created over waterfront reform, we do not believe we can accept your amendment or your general assurances that this money will automatically be spent to the benefit of waterfront reform in the way in which, in common terms, ordinary Australians would expect it to be spent.

Although you call it a levy, for all intents and purposes it is a tax on all stevedoring companies, irrespective of whether they were involved in the conspiracy to destroy the Maritime Union of Australia and its workers—and we will get to that a bit later. Sealand in South Australia will have to pay it. Even though they were quite happy with the arrangements and discussions with the union to get improved productivity in South Australia, they will have to pay the levy.

The government made it quite clear at the time of the debate that they disagreed with the Sealand view of how to conduct waterfront reform. How do we know that, although you raised the money from them, you will not use their money to make payments to one of their competitors, the Corrigan company? That is what is open. You would say that governments would be open to considerable criticism if they tried that sort of approach. This government have been very thick-skinned over criticism of their handling of waterfront reform. The only reason this bill is before us is that the whole of the waterfront reform policy of this government has ended up in ignominious defeat, as I said yesterday.

This bill started off, of course, as a way to pay out all the sacked workers that Mr Corrigan wanted to get rid of as part of the government's plan. Now that you have retreated and been defeated on this issue, we accept that the redundancy payments should be paid as an agreement between the workers and the company. But we cannot accept the word that you have given here or the assurances you have given in view of the track record of this government generally on water front matters in the last few months. Therefore, we will insist on our amendments.

talk.start.para: —I wonder if I could address through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, a question to Senator Schacht concerning amendment (4) which we are dealing with on page 1041. Senator Schacht, I could not find definitions of `stevedoring companies' or `employers' in the bill, although there is a definition of `stevedoring industry'. It occurs to us that there may be a problem with your amendment (4) because it could result in payments not being capable of being made to a parent company.

speech.para: As I understand it, the stevedoring companies which are employers in the Patrick's situation at the moment are subsidiaries, and those subsidiaries are without any money. For them to receive money to pay these redundancies, it would probably have to come through the parent company. I may or may not be right on this because I have not been party to those matters.

I also do not know, with regard to any other stevedoring companies, what their corporate structure is. It seems to me that, if there is an indirect process whereby the payments actually come from a company which is not the direct employer—which is, in fact, contracting to a stevedoring group—we could have a problem with it. I just ask you the question: are you able to satisfy me that amendment (4) does not, in fact, exclude some possible employees from accessing this fund as a result of being made redundant?

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the payment will be made to Patrick companies 1, 2 and 3—the employment companies—and, even though they were asset stripped, the employment arrangements are still with those companies and therefore the payment will be made to those employees in those companies. Therefore, we believe that there is not a problem of the money being diverted to be paid to shell companies. Although they are shell companies in terms of asset stripping, they are still the companies, I am advised, that employ those stevedores that are being made redundant.

—Thank you, Senator Schacht. Minister, am I right: is there some danger here that some companies or employees could be excluded because of the insufficient definitions attached to (4)? Am I on the wrong track here?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —We think you are on the right track. The difficulty we have with this whole series of amendments is that they are far too narrowly focused. That is the classic unintended consequence, or it may be intended. It would certainly be very unfair if it were to have the effect that you apprehend, and I do not think we would be wanting to take that sort of a risk.

speech.para: The irony of this in many ways is that, if you took the approach advocated by the opposition, you would essentially only be able to make payments to people who are made redundant. Therefore, if people want payments, they effectively have to leave. We want the flexibility to pay people like Sealand or other small employers who may be prepared to make improved productivity arrangements without actually reducing their work forces. That would be very much in aid of achieving waterfront reform, but it would not result in redundancies.

Under the opposition's approach, no payment would be able to be made because all that you can do is pay people who are made redundant. So the ironic effect of your approach, Senator Schacht, would be to provide incentives for people to be forced out of the work force, rather than for them to be kept in the work force but working more efficiently. That is why we think our flexibility is vastly more desirable than simply the narrow targeted approach of effectively putting people on the equivalent of welfare, as you would do, rather than looking at the ultimate objective which is to increase the levels of productivity for the existing work force.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that this amendment was drafted very carefully on advice in view of very detailed consultation with the union which represents the workers who are being made redundant and it is very confident that this amendment does it.

speech.para: Senator Heffernan interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You may laugh, Senator Heffernan, but we are not afraid of having consultations with the MUA and with any other union and group in the community. We do not black-ban and lock out people, put dogs onto them and wear balaclavas at midnight. We do not treat Australian workers that way.

speech.para: We are very pleased to be able to have those discussions. We would be stupid to draft amendments about which we did not seek consultation with the union and the workers it represents. The union is confident that this means that the workers who are eligible—who are employed in those Patrick's companies—will be guaranteed of getting the payment under the definition in this, Senator Murray. That is my advice.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —We do not support the amendment because its purpose is to confine payments to established stevedores. It assumes that all potentially redundant employees during the operation of the reform arrangements will be employees of stevedoring companies which were the actual employers of stevedoring labour on 30 June 1997. This may have the unfair result that some employees who should be entitled to their full redundancy payments would miss out because of a statutory restriction. For example, if the continuing employment of some employees was not resolved until reform related restructuring had been put in place, redundancy payments would not be available to them.

—I do not disagree with the minister: that is the purpose and the intent and that is what people believe this legislation is about. The minister keeps raising as an aside, `We need flexibility to do something else,' but he does not give us an example of what that flexibility is. Even the one you gave there, Minister—
—Training in new technologies and occupational health and safety. You want to sack people.

—That is the very point. Minister, we do not trust you when you start raising issues of new technology. We have certainly always accepted training matters, occupational health matters, et cetera. But the way you use it is as a weapon to create instability and also to have flexibility to make payments way beyond what normal workers would expect from this bill and its intent.

speech.para: We just do not trust the government. That is why we are tight with these definitions. We want the money to be spent in the way in which the agreement has been reached, and not find out later there were some side payments going off to Mr Corrigan for other purposes or for other stevedoring companies to suit the political agenda of this government.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I should have said this earlier, as it might have helped the Senate. If you look at our amendments, at the bottom of that page in clause (2) you will see (4). The effect of (4) is to say that no payments could be made pursuant to regulation until the expiration of the period by which regulations could be disallowed. In other words, it would not be open to us to make payments without any parliamentary scrutiny. We would have to proclaim the regulation—in other words, spell out what we had in mind—and it would only be if the parliament allowed that to occur that the payments would then be made. So you retain full parliamentary scrutiny over any payments. It is quite transparent. Again, I say that under our model you would provide incentives for people to remain in the workplace but be able to provide financial assistance for improved productivity measures, whereas going down your path you would be providing incentives for more and more people to leave the work force so they could take redundancy payments.

—Senator Schacht was taken to task because the opposition amendments on 1041 used the expression `stevedoring companies'. When I say `taken to task', I mean that he was asked about that as if that was a concept that needed to be defined. But the Democrat amendments on page 1054, for example, talk about stevedoring industries, and the definition in the bill itself talks about stevedoring industries. The government amendments talk about stevedoring work. Everybody knows what is meant by stevedoring companies or industries or work. It seems a very interesting point to take, that when the opposition tries to bring some rectitude to the way this money is going to be spent, people suddenly find that it is very difficult to get the concept of what stevedoring is all about when the whole debate has been based on that concept. It seems to me quite clear what opposition amendments Nos 1, 3 and 4 talk about. People should not slide away from that simply because they suddenly find it difficult to understand what `stevedoring' means.

—Minister, all of us are very conscious—and in fact I have just had a discussion with Senator Schacht on this—of the pressure of bills and legislative work which is before us, and there is the prospect, as we all know, that we may not return to this place until after an election. That being so, what is the likely fate of amendments to this bill that go down to the House? What is the government's view of both how it would consider those amendments and in what way legislation could be returned to the Senate if amendments are rejected?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —We have every intention of taking the bill back to the House of Representatives so that we can consummate the agreements as quickly as possible. Obviously, if it contains unacceptable amendments that will not be able to occur then the whole deal will effectively be off. We are not concerned with election timetables, we simply want to get this—
—The case is back on, though.

—No, we want to get this in place as quickly as possible. If the amendments that are acceptable to the government are put in place then it goes straight back to the House of Representatives, it becomes law, and you can, as I say, consummate the agreements that have already been signed. If it does not, then of course we will not be able to take it any further and the deal will be off.

—Thank you, Minister, for that answer. The opposition has quite rightly made the point that this whole unsavoury exercise has generated a most unfortunate consequent lack of trust about all these issues. However, the prime thing in my mind is the employees. I am deeply concerned that amendment No. 4 may have unforeseen problems attached to it. That is all. My concern is that no employee of any stevedoring company should be in any sense denied access to these funds. The reason I have become concerned and alarmist is due to the restructuring problems that we saw with Patrick. I just do not know what is out there. Frankly, I have not done the research and I do not know how the companies are structured.

speech.para: Obviously, I am a strong supporter of amendment No. 1 because it is our own amendment and the opposition have put very adequate arguments. I am somewhat helped by the government's own amendment. In a narrow sense, you have addressed some of the issues that concern us. In particular, I note item (1)(c) on the government amendment. I assume, Minister, that those would be disallowable regulations, which would assist the Senate if any payments for any activities were envisaged which were in the category that Senator Schacht and his colleagues rightfully are concerned about as possibilities. I advise you, Senator Schacht, that my intention therefore is to vote against your amendment No. 4 and I would like to hear from the minister whether he thinks it is likely that amendments Nos 1 to 3 would be seriously considered in the House of Representatives as appropriate amendments.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I think I have already indicated that we would regard them as fundamentally unacceptable because they are far too narrow. The effect of them would be that they would simply focus on redundancies, so you would be in effect driving people out of the work force to take the money rather than trying to achieve our fundamental objective of restructuring.
—That is what the levy is for. It is a levy for redundancies.

—It is not. We want the flexibility to be able to use that levy for the purposes of promoting restructuring and reform that result in increased productivity. There may well be all or some of those stevedoring employers who come to the government and say, `We have a very sensible approach that will not involve any reduction in the work force but that will, however, result in substantial increases in productivity.' That is essentially an application of those funds and we would be very much wanting to do that.

speech.para: The answer to Senator Murray in relation to 1(c) is that (4), beneath (2), says:
(4) The Minister cannot authorise payments under paragraph (I)(c) or (I)(d) . . . until after the end of the period within which those regulations can be disallowed . . .

I hope that makes it clear that we simply would not have the capacity to go off and provide the funds for something the parliament might regard as quite unacceptable. It could only be after the period of disallowance had expired—in other words, the parliament had effectively approved the purpose—that we would then be able to make the payments. That is a very important safeguard. It has been put in deliberately. It does address those concerns but still retains the flexibility to have regulations that will allow you to promote real reforms rather than simply handing out money to people who are made redundant.

talk.start.para: —I have just been advised that the phrase `flexibility to promote real reform' was not an issue raised with the opposition when this bill came into the lower house or raised with the shadow minister, Mr Tanner. Whether Senator Alston, as the minister representing the minister, Mr Reith, has used that phrase of his own invention, I do not know.
—I would have said, `for example'.

—This is why we are concerned. The government keeps shifting the description and the nature of what they think is the purpose of this bill and the money raised by this tax on all stevedoring companies other than those in the domestic area. If the regulation stands up, the money is, according to the minister, for redundancies. It is now being put to us that the government, according to the minister representing Mr Reith, wants flexibility. On this particular issue we do not believe, and cannot trust, the government on a phrase like `flexibility'. Its track record on its so-called `agenda of reform' is to say one thing in the parliament and secretly do something else quite different behind the backs of everybody. It is just a further concern to us.

speech.para: The minister may well have been honest for the first time in describing some of the policy intent and saying that they need this flexibility. In that sense I thank him. But it further raises our concern about what is really going on here. To use the classic analogy, which even the minister would understand, in Aussie Rules football terms the government is shifting the goalposts from full-forward around to the half-forward flank and expecting us still to accept that nothing has changed. We do not accept that. We do not trust the government on this. Those phrases that the minister just used create considerable concern in our minds that the government is changing its agenda on how it wants to use this substantial amount of money—a tax on stevedoring companies. That is why we want to define it. We do not trust the government in relation to how it would use this money, even through a disallowable instrument. We all know that a disallowable instrument is much harder—you can knock it back or defeat it but the government always has the drop in cases of regulation. You have to keep defeating a regulation and then you put a new one in and until the new one is voted on, the old—

talk.start.para: —We could never make any payments until we got it through.

—That is the blackmail you would use. The political blackmail would be, `If you do not accept this regulation now no payment will be made.' You would be in the Senate saying, `The Labor Party is refusing to support this regulation and by refusing it no payment will be made.' That is exactly how governments use the power over regulation as a way to get their will. On waterfront reform, as the government calls it, we do not trust this government. We do expect that you would come back here and put that political blackmail to us, saying, `This is the regulation you will cop or no payment will be made.' We are put in Hobson's choice—between the frying pan and the fire. That is why, Minister, we are going to stick with this amendment. I would still ask Senator Murray, in view of what the minister has just said, to support us, even in amendment (4).

—I would not use exactly the same language as Senator Schacht, but I share his lack of trust and his concern and the very real anxiety we all have arising from this situation. I will not change my mind on amendment (4) because I do think there is a danger some employees could be excluded.

speech.para: Dealing with (1) and (3): Senator Schacht has discussed political blackmail. I have not been subjected to it; I have been rung by Minister Reith—

talk.start.para: —So have I.

—I am sure you have. He is by all means an assiduous worker in these matters. His message to me was the same message as he has put out publicly, and that is simply that he wants his bill urgently and he does not want it changed. That puts me and the Democrats over a barrel. I am capable of staring down the government when the issue so arises, but on this issue I find myself in a real difficulty. At stake is a major agreement that has finally been brokered, a cessation of legal actions which could have enormous consequences for the participants—
—Don't you think the government wants it stopped?

—I am sure they do. Nevertheless, as Senator O'Brien knows, in any action there are always the dangers to both sides of costs and troubles. And at stake, primarily for me, are the workers and their families. In public I have been consistently asked, `What would be your approach?' I have said that it is impossible for me as a person to look into the baby blues of workers and their families and say, `I will put at risk their funds.'

speech.para: My only approach, given the government's response and the lifeline that is there in their amendments, however circumscribed that lifeline is, is to recommend to my party room that we abstain on this. I do not want to be in a situation where we vote with you—and we agree with your amendments, let me tell you that; as you know we have put up the same amendments—and this bill goes back to the House of Representatives and they reject the amendments and we are left with a real problem. I advise you that, if it came back here, I would not insist on it—on the basis of my belief that those workers and their families have to be secured as urgently as possible.

I know it is probably not good tactics to say here and now how I would behave, but I want you to fully understand the dilemma I face.
