They said, `Yes, an hour or so.' Senator Calvert was at the meeting. The agreement was that we would finish stevedoring in an hour, do a little bit of digital and get on to the appropriations by midday so we would have the appropriations bills finished.

Senator Carr seems to be following on from the track record he had when he was a Labor Party operative in Victoria. The former Premier of Victoria, John Cain, has very strong views about how Senator Carr's words should be taken.

Madam President, I say to you that Senator Carr should, at the earliest occasion, put out a release apologising to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, Mr Peter Reith, and he should tell the truth about who wanted to pull the electoral bill last night and bring on stevedoring. He should tell the truth about the fact that the Labor Party had agreed that we should be able to get stevedoring finished in an hour this morning. He should tell the truth about the fact that the Labor Party will do anything and say anything to look cooperative but, when it comes to delivering on their agreements, they will not do so.

The Liberal Party and the government in this place reached an informal agreement with the Australian Labor Party that we would recall an estimates committee to allow Senator Peter Cook to ask questions of Treasury officials. Part of the informal agreement—as there can always be—was that we would get an agreement from the Australian Labor Party to assist in speeding up the program with the passage of the electoral bill and the stevedoring bill last night.

The coalition delivered its side of a sensible arrangement in full, on time and for the entire time. We had the Secretary to the Department of the Treasury sitting upstairs in committee room 2S1. Senator Cook wanted to drag Treasury back and subject them and you, Senator Kemp, to probing questions. I went up there to see Senator Cook tearing the Treasury officials and the Assistant Treasurer to bits with his probing questions. I have got to say that a Senate committee room was not the right place to have that estimates hearing. The right thing, Senator Kemp, I would have thought, would be to have Senator Cook, the Secretary to the Department of the Treasury and the Assistant Treasurer sitting around a lounge room with a nice fire going and a couple of glasses of brandy on the side. Senator Cook was trying to overcome his relevance deprivation syndrome in trying to talk to the head of one of the big departments in this government. He wanted to share notes with Ted Evans and Senator Kemp about the state of the world economy and try to play games.

It was a very nice three hours, Senator Kemp, I think. In fact, I think, Madam President, you could suggest to the Joint House Committee that we investigate having fireplaces installed in some committee rooms so that we can ensure that estimates committees proceed in a friendly, pleasant `fireside chat' manner so that Senator Cook, Mr Evans and Senator Kemp can chat about the world economy.

The point is, of course, that the government delivered on its commitments and the Australian Labor Party, as usual, failed to deliver on their side of the bargain. They said that stevedoring would be half an hour to an hour maximum. That means it would have been finished by 10.30. It finished at about ten to one. Senator Alston, I guess the point is that their promises in relation to the hours it takes to do a piece of legislation are very similar to their promises on delivering balanced budgets. They said, `We'll deliver surpluses,' and they deliver deficits. They say, `We've delivered a surplus,' and their deficit is $12 billion, year on year. You cannot trust them with money. You cannot trust them at all. If you want something from the Labor Party, get it in writing. (Time expired)

—I want to address some of the issues that arise out of the question I asked the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman, yesterday. I know some of my colleagues on the other side have had a bit of fun with the ball, but it is about to be returned with some gratuitous comments.
—Not like you, George.

—Not like me at all, Senator Kemp. The question I asked of Senator Newman yesterday was based on information which had been provided to me by members of my union in New South Wales who had gone to the Centrelink offices in Wollongong and been advised that, as a result of changes that were due and effective from 1 July 1998, construction workers would, in certain circumstances, be deemed as `seasonal workers'. As a result of that, I organised to have a question asked of the minister yesterday which went to the question of whether or not the minister could confirm the advice that was given by Centrelink to construction workers in respect of them being deemed `seasonal workers'—a change in the way in which they had been treated in the past.

speech.para: The minister's response to that question, in my view, was flippant in that she drew my attention to the legislation that had just passed through the Senate a few minutes before question time took place. She did not at any time during that process attempt to answer the substance of my question. I must admit that I was a bit surprised at the minister's response and I did think at the time I had been sold a furphy, so to speak, in the terms of the advice I had received.

Since that time I have gone and made some inquiries on the matter and, in particular, on the legislation that was passed by the Senate yesterday just prior to question time. Those on this side of the chamber who were involved in the negotiations around that legislation have advised me that never at any time during the negotiations over that legislation were construction workers discussed in terms of what was defined as `seasonal worker'. In the view of those on this side of the chamber who were involved in those negotiations, it was never intended that construction workers would be caught by the definition of `seasonal worker' in the act.
Schedule 4 of the legislation, which refers to the position of seasonal workers, has two definitions. Section 16A sets out those definitions. It states in (1)(a) that seasonal work means:

. . . work that, because of its nature or of factors peculiar to the industry in which it is performed, is available, at approximately the same time or times every year, for part or parts only of the year . . .

I do not think there is any way anyone could construe that definition as applying to a construction worker. Essentially, a construction worker is employed in the industry for 52 weeks of the year—if he can get 52 weeks work in a year—on a full-time basis. The work construction workers get may well be irregular, but I believe that no-one could define it in any way as being `seasonal' or as coming within the definition of `seasonal work' as covered by section 16A(1)(a). Section 16A(1)((b) states:
. . . work that is intermittent and is determined, under subsection (2), to be seasonal work for the purposes of this Act.

Subsection (2) requires the making of a disallowable instrument by the secretary in order to specify the type of work that is covered by that section. If the minister is using subsection (2) to define that construction workers are covered by the provisions of that legislation passed yesterday, then it will require an instrument to be tabled in this parliament.

I take this opportunity to advise the minister that, if an instrument is sought to be tabled in the parliament to include construction workers in that definition, the opposition will oppose the allowance of that instrument. From talking to my colleagues, it is quite clear that never at any time, in the sorts of examples that were given by the minister or the persons negotiating on her behalf, was a construction worker conceived to fall within either of one of those two definitions.

In those circumstances, I think it appropriate for the minister to come into this chamber on the next day of sitting, preferably before question time, and give us an explanation defining which of those sections she was relying on yesterday when she answered my question. If she believes that construction workers were caught by the legislation that was passed yesterday by the Senate—and it is my view that she did not even understand her own legislation, otherwise she would not have answered my question in the way she did—then I would ask her to come into this chamber on Monday prior to question time and give us an explanation, or provide me with an explanation, as to which of the two definitions she believes a construction worker is caught under.

If she does not or cannot give an explanation, or if she believes on examination that they are not caught by those provisions, then I think she owes it to construction workers all around the country to advise Centrelink personally that they or the people who have been turned away be advised that in fact they received wrong advice from Centrelink, that they are not caught by the definition and that they do have access to the jobsearch allow ance in the same way as any other unemployed person would have access to that allowance.

I think the minister at least owes that to the persons in Wollongong who, in my view, have been misled by the advice given by Centrelink. Centrelink itself obviously have been advised wrongly by the department or by the minister's office as to the application of those definitions and the categories of employment that fall within those two definitions provided for in schedule 4 of the legislation that was passed yesterday. That, I think, is the least that the minister and the department can do in clearing this matter up.

I think she owes an apology to construction workers. I do not take kindly to the way in which the minister treated the question. It does not matter how this might affect me—the minister might want to have a bit of fun in the chamber. There are workers out there who are struggling to try to get a week's work. They are struggling to try to get continuity of employment in the same way that it is guaranteed to us. They are trying to use the already discredited job search services that this government put in place from 1 May and are being given wrong advice. When we seek to try to have this corrected, we are treated flippantly and with total disregard by the minister. I think this is totally disrespectful of these workers.

In those circumstances, I think the least the minister can do is review the contents of the question she was asked yesterday, examine the question against the legislation, try to understand what her own legislation actually means, work out who will be caught by the seasonal worker provisions and, if she is big enough to admit she was wrong, at least ensure that Centrelink, if not herself personally, offers an apology to those workers who have been turned away under those provisions.

talk.start.para: —There has been a lot of commentary in recent months about the possibility and probability of a race based federal election. A lot of that has focused around the issue of native title, which is obviously an important one. But another component of that which is also crucial to the future direction of our nation is the issue of our immigration policy and our multicultural policy. The future direction of those crucial issues is very much in the balance as we move towards an election, whether it is an earlier one or whether it is held later next year. I think it is important to emphasise to the people of Australia that they will face a crucial choice in that area.

speech.para: As opinion polls have shown, there is quite a strong possibility that the One Nation party, which has a policy, or has made many pronouncements, which are clearly anti-migrant and anti-multiculturalism—and anti-Asian immigration, in particular—is in a position where they may actually have the balance of power in this chamber. Whilst I am sure many Australians have differing views about the effectiveness or otherwise of the Democrats' role in holding the balance of power in the Senate over many years, I think the Australian nation faces a grave danger when it comes down to a choice between the Australian Democrats or One Nation holding that important position of responsibility of the balance of power.

We have the prospect of a party that is clearly racially intolerant, that is anti-multiculturalism and that seeks to promote those particular policies, holding the balance of power. Balance that against the approach that the Democrats have taken over many years: promoting tolerance, multiculturalism and the important role that migrants play in our society. It would be a sad day indeed if a party that had policies such as One Nation was able to exercise influence and sway over the government of the day by virtue of their position in the Senate.

Recently, there have been a number of quite dishonest attempts by the One Nation party and others to try to create an impression that the immigration policy of the Democrats is the same as that of One Nation. The fact that One Nation is quite happy to peddle this fiction just shows that they are quite happy to tell what are, clearly, untruths whenever it suits their purposes. It seems to me that the defacto leader of the One Nation party, Mr David Oldfield, has a willingness to stretch the truth to such a magnitude that it would even make people such as Graham Richardson blush.

With Mr Oldfield's announcement this week in the Australian that he wants to contest a Senate seat in NSW and try to enter this particular chamber, it may well be that the battle for the balance of power in the Senate may come down to the outcome in New South Wales. David Oldfield is a man who attacks multiculturalism, frequently talks about `useless migrants', proudly proclaims himself to be `culturally intolerant', and seems to think that there is no problem about that. Even again today, he was quite happy to complain, threaten and make dark inferences about the `threatening Asianisation of Australia' at the same time as trying to suggest that he does not support racial discrimination.

Voters will have a choice between that person and the Democrats' Senate candidate Aden Ridgeway, who is well known to many as head of the New South Wales Aboriginal Land Council. You probably could not get a better representation of the two opposite moral values our two parties represent.

As all Australia knows, One Nation are proud to promote intolerance and bigotry—as their frequently repeated comments about the `Asianisation of Australia' make clear. By contrast, the Democrats are proud to support and promote multiculturalism—not because it is a nice feel-good thing, but because it makes Australia stronger, both socially and economically.

Australian society is second only to Israel in the number of nations from which its citizens have been drawn. This is clearly one of our strengths. Immigration and multiculturalism has added to our cultural experiences and to our economic ability to explore and to expand trade opportunities. To put that at risk is potentially damaging to all of Australia and to our future economic development. Obviously, it is particularly dangerous and unwelcome for people who are recent migrants to this country, for people wanting to migrate to this country and for people who are wanting to contribute to this country and to be made to feel welcome.

The Democrats' policy on immigration and multiculturalism has long been public and clear in its goals and objectives. It is a wide ranging policy which embraces and gives equal treatment to people from all national and cultural backgrounds. We believe that all of us, no matter where we come from, have a part to play in building a strong, safe, harmonious and prosperous Australia. It is counterproductive to try to make it harder for people to be able to contribute fully to our community.

The Australian Democrats have consistently and strongly supported the concept of multiculturalism and have taken action on numerous occasions to make it a reality. We will continue to do so, despite the current political fashion and the political correctness against multiculturalism that seems to be gaining pace. People who were born in other countries have made a significant contribution to Australian society and continue to do so. The Democrats believe that a cohesive, multicultural society will be maintained and developed only if people from all backgrounds, including people of non-English speaking backgrounds, from all parts of the world are able to achieve equality in access to the services and the opportunities open to all Australians.

That is a principle the Democrats have pursued by many actions over many years, perhaps none more so than trying to fight what I believe is a clear indication of a sign of things to come if we continue down a negative path in this direction: that is, the outrageous, discriminatory and unfair provision that currently exists for people who have migrated to this country having to wait two years before they have the same right as any other legitimate resident of Australia to have access to social security payments in times of need. The Democrats are committed to equal treatment of migrants. We believe this measure reinforces a negative principle, and I believe it will be one of many, many more measures if the current fashionable tide of rhetoric against migrants continues. It is being promoted that migrants are useless or are a drain on society rather than recognising that they are a benefit to Australian society economically and socially. It is crucial that those non-facts are shown for the falsehoods that they are.

By contrast with the Democrats' goals, a quick visit to One Nation's web site displays that party's goals. They have only six apparently at the moment. Goal No. 1, the top of their list, is to reduce immigration until unemployment is addressed. It perpetuates the myth that migrants take the jobs of Australians. Time after time studies show that migrants assist in generating employment and generating a healthier economy for Australia. So their top priority is based on a total myth. It once again shows how ill-informed and lacking in economic credibility One Nation is, let alone its socially destructive message.

Another of the six One Nation goals repeats a commitment to abolish multiculturalism. How you abolish something that is reality is not actually spelt out. Perhaps it means that One Nation is proposing to send all those Australians who were born in other countries back to the place of their birth or even back to the place of their parents' birth. Anybody who has any cultural traits that do not fit their desired view for monoculturalism is somehow or other meant to be abolished. Exactly how this might be done is a frightening thought when one thinks through what it might actually mean. Again, these sorts of things are hidden behind the new politically correct terminology which people such as Mr Oldfield use; terms such as cultural intolerance, which he is using to replace the word racism. Those sorts of statements need to be shown up for what they are, which is basically a politically correct way of saying racist.

By contrast, the Democrats' objectives entrenched and enshrined in our party's constitution include a recognition of the interdependence of all people and a support for further developing a multifaceted national culture with full opportunity for all ethnic groups to contribute. It highlights the crucial choice that this nation faces in many regards as we move towards the next election. I urge all Australians to think carefully about the future direction of our nation, not just as it might affect people from non-English speaking backgrounds and migrant backgrounds but also how it will affect all of us. If our nation's social fabric is torn asunder, decisiveness and derision will be introduced into the community and the economic value that plays such a marvellous role in developing Australia that all migrants and multiculturalism in general have provided for us will be affected. If that risk is not recognised, then I fear we will have perpetual damage made to our nation's future which will take generations to overcome.

talk.start.para: —Today I wanted to talk about the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and his family. You will recall that immediately after the last election there was considerable public debate about where the Prime Minister planned to live. Prime Ministers usually live in the Lodge. The last Prime Minister to live in Sydney was Sir William McMahon. People are increasingly noting the similarities between the prime ministerships of Messrs McMahon and Howard. They can add the fact that both lived in Sydney to that list.

speech.para: The Lodge has always been the official residence, but Mr Howard said he wanted to spend more time in Sydney to minimise disruption to his family. Of course, he did not seem to give any consideration to the disruption caused to many Canberra families by the significant increase in the time public servants would be required to spend in Sydney or the increased burden on the Australian taxpayer of the costs associated with running government out of Sydney rather than the national political capital. Clearly the Prime Minister had the wellbeing of his family very high on his list of priorities, as do many fathers.

There was one such father at last night's meeting in the central Queensland town of Wondi attended by Mr Howard. This father said that while his family was going downhill the Prime Minister's family was okay. He told Mr Howard that his sympathy for the plight of people living in rural Australia would not pay the family bills. On the ABC's AM this morning that father told the Prime Minister his sympathy would not help him to `give my family the life I want to give them'. He stated:
I feel that my family is going to go downhill while your family is still surviving and getting what you want your family to have.
He also said:
My family won't have that.

There are now hundreds of thousands of families living in regional Australia who are being forced to face the reality that, through government inaction or misguided policies, they cannot properly support their families.

Yesterday five more families found themselves out of work because of the failure of this government to support regional Australia. At the close of business yesterday the Tasmanian Pig Cooperative was forced to close its doors. Five workers lost their jobs and, therefore, five families must now face the prospect of getting by without that wage coming in. There are another eight positions that are under review as a result of the cooperative's closure. Mr Howard and his minister Mr Anderson could have acted to support the Australian pork industry last year. They could have put in place assistance packages that might have enabled the industry to get through the crisis that it has faced in the last 30 years. They could have taken action, legal action, to stem the flood of imported meat. If they had, the cooperative might still be trading and five people might be looking forward to the next pay packet, but Mr Anderson, Mr Fischer and now Mr Howard chose to ignore these rural families. So in the name of free trade five jobs go, eight more are under threat and 13 more fathers cannot give their kids the lives that they deserve. Mr Howard has to give as much consideration to the future of these families and their children as he does his own.

Mr Howard was not the only person to cop a blast last night. Another speaker at the Wondai meeting said this of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Anderson, and I again quote from the ABC AM program:
I think the most unpopular, detested man in Australia is your Minister for primary industries John Anderson.

That was on the tape from one of the audience. There was a huge cheer from the 600-strong crowd in response to that statement. On Wednesday I raised the matter of the poor standing that Mr Anderson has in the bush generally and in his electorate of Gwydir in particular. I mentioned the fact that the President of the Manilla branch of the National Party, Mr Jim Maxwell, has stated on the record that Mr Anderson had deserted the people who put him there. The Queensland grain growers have voted in support of a motion of no confidence in Mr Anderson, as have the Queensland pig producers and the national pig body as well.

The minister has also been under attack from the grain industry, sections of the wool industry, the beef industry and the chicken industry. The claim last night that Mr Anderson is the most detested and unpopular man in Australia appears well placed. It seems there is one thing that Mr Howard could do that will cost nothing but would get a big tick from across rural Australia, and that is to replace Mr Anderson with someone who can relate to the needs of people in the bush.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 25 May 1998:

question.para: With reference to an article in the Thai press in December 1997 which reported the Minister as promoting the sale of Australian military equipment in that country, despite the downturn in the economy leading to the cancellation of major weapons contracts:
